title: Untitled

thumbnail.alt_text: Large painting on seven panels of dark landscape with small abstract shapes.

description:
The largely self-taught Yves Tanguy decided to become an artist around 1923, when he was inspired by a painting by Giorgio de Chirico that he saw in a shop window. Tanguy became interested in Surrealism a year later, after reading the periodical La révolution surréaliste. André Breton welcomed him into the Surrealist group in 1925. Inspired by the metaphysical qualities of de Chirico’s work, as well as the biomorphic forms of Jean Arp, Max Ernst, and Joan Miró, Tanguy quickly developed his own fantastic vocabulary of organic, amoeba-like shapes that populate mysterious, dreamlike settings.

Tanguy painted this primordial landscape on a hinged wooden screen. Little information exists about the circumstances of the work’s making, but the artist probably intended it for a patron’s home, since many Surrealists were interested in the decorative arts and produced folding screens, furniture, and other domestic objects. In this unusual example, although the screen retains the potential to close off the private sphere, it simultaneously opens up more intimate dreams and fantasies to the outside world.
dimensions: Two sets of four joined panels, each panel: 200.1 × 59.7 cm (78 3/4 × 23 1/2 in.)

dimensions_detail.clarification: Two sets of four joined panels, each panel

publication_history:
Art Institute of Chicago Annual Report, 1988-89, p. 29 (ill.).

Charles F. Stuckey, French Painting (New York: Hugh Lauter Levin Associates, 1991), p. 266 (ill.).

James N. Wood and Teri J. Edelstein, The Art Institute of Chicago: Twentieth-Century Painting and Sculpture (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1996), p. 58 (ill.).

Karin von Maur, et al., Yves Tanguy and Surrealism (Ostfildern-Ruit: Hatje Cantz, 2001), p. 74, fig. 62

Stephanie D’Alessandro and Renée DeVoe Mertz, The Age of Picasso and Matisse: Modern Art at the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 2014), 129 (color ill.)..
exhibition_history:
Paris, Centre Georges Pompidou, Yves Tanguy: Retrospective, 1925-1955, June 17–September 27, 1982, ill. p. 49 (detail) in French ed.; traveled to Baden-Baden, Staatliche Kunsthalle, October 17, 1982–January 2, 1983, ill. opp. p. 49 in German ed. (detail).

Washington, D.C., National Gallery of Art, The Folding Image, March 4–September 3, 1984, no. 28.1/28.2; traveled to New Haven, Yale University Art Gallery, October 11, 1984–January 6, 1985, no. 28, Ill. pp. 250-51 (detail).
provenance_text: Henri Creuzevelt [email from Charles Stuckey, Head of Research, Yves Tanguy Catalogue Raisonné, Aug. 1, 2019; photocopy in curatorial file]. Charles Ratton, Paris, after Jan. 31, 1963 [Paris 1964]. Galerie André-François Petit, Paris, by 1982 [Paris 1982]; sold to the Art Institute, 1988.
